experience.title: IT Security
experience.description:
In order that test execution and results can be verified, only the following tools have been
approved for use:
Tool Automated / Manual
CSDA (Core Security Design Assessment)
Manual
Veracode (SAST) Automated
ZAP (Zed Attack Proxy) (DAST)
Automated
HP Web Inspect (DAST) Automated


Although the configuration and use of the tools is not described here, accepted best-practice
methods and techniques should be used in order that tests are accurate, consistent and repeatable.


 2.2 REQUIREMENTS
 * Security requirements for all initiatives will be determined by CSDA (Core Security Design
 Assessment) which are initially completed by the solution / security architect.
 * If SAST (Static Application Security Testing) or DAST (Dynamic Application Security Testing)
 are required, these will be delivered via engagement with $ADM Security - Engagement mailbox.
 * Security testing covers internal and industry standards such as ITEC, OWASP, SANS and PCI DSS.
 * Automated testing alone is not sufficient to validate all of the security controls required in
 CSDA. Manual testing may also be required for any controls which cannot be automated.
 * Penetration testing requires engagement with $ mailbox
 * Applications which have known security issues or existing waivers must be fixed and resolved
 within the agreed timescales of the waiver e.g. during warranty or prior to the next release.


 2.3 ENVIRONMENT
Early security testing can take place in sandbox environments but should be performed on BR
environments prior to go-live. Automated tools can be used and integrated as part of development /
build.
SIT / NFT BR environments will be used to scan code and ensure no critical or high security
vulnerabilities are present prior to go live. For mobile initiatives, this will require engagement
with IT Security for penetration testing.


 2.4 DEFINITION OF DONE
 * Security testing has completed when all requirements have been met using the toolset and
 environments outlined in sections 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3.
 * All Critical and High security vulnerabilities must be fixed before the application / changes
 go live.
 * Remediation plans must be provided and agreed for resolving any Medium security
 vulnerabilities
 * CSDA must be updated upon completion of security testing to evidence the final outcome and
 security position. Penetration testing sign off must be provided by IT Security if confirmed
 in scope.


 2.5 QAE REPRESENTATIVE RESPONSIBILITES
The QAE representative has responsilibty to ensure security test principles detailed in Section 1
are properly followed and met the requirements detailed in Section 2 using appropriate tools,
environments and evidence.
They will also have accountability to ensure governance is followed if the definition of done has
not been achieved. For example, if any Critial or High vulnerabilities have not been fixed prior to
go live this will require consultation with ITBUCF security advisor and a formal waiver.



 3. GUIDANCE
 * All initiatives or sprints need to be risk assessed for security requirements (standalone and
 BR)
 * Security testing should be carried out as early as possible to improve quality and reduce risk
 * Use automated tools to ensure common security issues are fixed during development
 * Use manual testing to identify vulnerabilities which cannot be uncovered using automated
 techniques
 * For evidence, the CSDA template needs to be updated and will be used for audit purposes
 * Detailed security reports will not be included in stakeholder deliverables due to sensitivity
 / confidentiality



 4. DEPENDENCIES
The following dependencies must be met before this strategy can be fully implemented. It is expected
that these will be common across all themes.
 * DAST requires engagement with $ADM Security - Engagement team.
 * Penetration testing requires engagement with $IT Security - Project Penetration Testing team.
 * Access to route to live environments is required with unique user credentials and test data.
 * It has been agreed with senior management that whilst ZAP can be used for automated security
 testing in build, HP Web Inspect must also be used to ensure Low severity vulnerabilities are
 also identified.
 * Security defects need to be raised in ALM / JIRA and tracked to closure as part of each
 release.
 * Security standards and waivers are maintained by IT Security / ITBUCF and not QA.



 5. APPROVAL LIST
Date Approver Role Version Signature
 Andrew Baker Digital Head of QE
 Mark Ramsay Vulnerability Management & Testing
 Duncan Hurwood IT Cyber Security
 James Mitman IT Security
 Athanasio Kontonasios Digital Security
